unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about the dosage of this new cough syrup, right? Well, Dr. Reddy prescribed it for my kid, Rohan, who's been down with a nasty cold. The bottle says 5ml for children aged 6-12 yrs, but Rohan is only 5. I was a bit confused.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about the dosage of this new cough syrup, right? Well, Doctor Reddy prescribed it for my kid, Rohan, who's been down with a nasty cold. The bottle says five milliliter for children aged six to twelve years, but Rohan is only five. I was a bit confused.

unnormalised: My wife, Priya, called up the clinic and spoke to a nurse there. Apparently, for kids under 6, it's usually 2.5 ml, but always check with your pediatrician, especially if your child is underweight or has any pre-existing conditions. Rohan weighs around 18 kg.
normalised: My wife, Priya, called up the clinic and spoke to a nurse there. Apparently, for kids under six, it's usually two point five milliliter, but always check with your pediatrician, especially if your child is underweight or has any pre-existing conditions. Rohan weighs around eighteen kilogram.

unnormalised: The nurse also mentioned that overdose symptoms include drowsiness and stomach upset. So, it's super important to measure accurately. She recommended using a proper oral syringe rather than just estimating with a teaspoon. Apparently, a teaspoon can vary quite a bit - some are 4 ml, others closer to 6 ml!
normalised: The nurse also mentioned that overdose symptoms include drowsiness and stomach upset. So, it's super important to measure accurately. unnormalised: Anyway, we ended up giving Rohan 2.5ml as advised. He seems to be doing better now. But seriously, medicine measurements can be a headache, especially when it comes to kids! Always err on the side of caution and consult a doc.
